✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Golfed it in C#. 127 characters.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easy.
Maybe add number theory as a tag?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple problem with appropriate difficulty rating and well defined test cases given the constraint range. Solvable with brute-force BFS (potentially could add as a tag).

Quick note: Rule 2 is just rule 1 but I suppose doesn't hurt to keep it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: An upperbound on the number of buttons is (length of n in binary + number of ones of n in binary), which is less than 40 given the constraint that n <= 10^6, so any graph pathfinding algorithm will do, no need to know anything about what the optimal solution looks like
I would change constraint so n can be 0, and in this case, the output should be 0 also.

Constraints
* Please change 10^9 to 10^6.

Cases
* Validator 4: Please change the input to 2047 so that it's also a power of 2 minus 1.

* Please add a pair of cases when n is a power of 2 (requiring one +1 and a series of x2).

* Please add a pair of cases when n is a power of 2 plus 1 (requiring one +1 and a series of x2 and another +1 at the end).

* Please add TWO PAIRS of cases when n is a random even integer. Currently there are NO visible tests featuring even numbers.

* Please add a pair of cases where n = 1 (edge case of requiring +1 only).

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.
Thank you. Please renumber the cases: Test 6 and Validator 6 are missing.
